description: This is the definitive trail in the dunes. It combines hiking through mature forests and along the top of a dune ridge overlooking Lake Michigan. The views are incredible. The gem of this trail is Beach House Blowout, a huge bowl of sand. The trail winds along its narrow edge affording views in every direction.

The Cowles Bog Trail highlights an area of such outstanding plant diversity that it was designated as a National Natural Landmark in 1965, a year before the Indiana Dunes National Park was established. This location, where Dr. Henry Cowles conducted much of his early work in plant ecology and succession in the early 1900s, remains an important focus for scientific study today.

Explore several distinct habitats along this 4.7-mile trail including ponds, marshes, swamps, black oak savannas and beaches. Steep sand dunes near Lake Michigan make this a very strenuous journey. Many visitors pack a lunch to enjoy at the shoreline while resting for the return trip (dont forget to pack out your trash). Make sure to bring plenty of water and sun protection.
Trail 8 climbs over the three tallest dunes in the park. There are great views at each peak.

This is a classic Yellowwood State Forest hike through Southern Indiana hardwood forests. Sustained climbs up long narrow ridge lines add a physical challenge, and hikes through deep hollows give a sense of true wilderness. The pinnacle of the hike is the summit of High King Hill, where excellent views of Yellowwood Lake await.
This hike combines the three different loops at West Beach. From the parking lot, follow the road north, toward the lake and pick up the trail to the east of the bathhouse.

Take the Paul H. Douglas Trail (formerly the Miller Woods Trail) through a globally rare oak savanna. The National Park Service conducts small, carefully controlled burns that mimic historic fires. These fires reduce the growth of woody species and the build-up of leaves on the forest floor. The savannas native grasses and wildflowers, including lupine, thrive in the sunlight and more open forest floor. The wild lupine, the only food for the caterpillar of the endangered Karner blue butterfly, grows close to the trail. Please stay single file on the narrow trail to protect yourself from the abundant poison ivy along the trail edges as well as the fragile lupine habitat.

The Nature Center features this trail as the 5-mile challenge. Hikers completing the hike in one day can receive a sticker when they take pictures of themselves at the Lusk Home (east), Camel's Back (north) and Boulder Canyon (west) for proof. 

The trail boasts 1,500 man-made steps spread out fairly evenly over the course of the trail, and allows hikers to see the best parts of the park by joining Trail #3, Trail #4, Trail #5, Trail #9, and Trail #10, into a single loop. The trail visits the Coal Mine, the Narrows Covered Bridge, Lusk Home, the Punch Bowl, Camel's Back, "140" steps, Boulder Canyon, Falls Canyon and many stream crossings, making the approximately six-mile hike very worthwhile. Parts of the trail require hikers to travel along as well as in the stream, so hikers should dress appropriately!

This is a fun eight-mile loop combining French Lick's Buffalo Trace Trail and Waterfall Trail. Hikers will tackle moderate to steady climbs and enjoy fun sections of descending. Expect some areas of rocky and technical trail and a beautiful, if smaller waterfall.

The Tolleston Dunes Trail follows 4,700 year-old sand dunes that were formed when Lake Michigan was 25 feet higher than in recent years. Tolleston is the second youngest of four distinct dune systems found within the national park. Together these dune ridges provide a glimpse into the changing shoreline of Lake Michigan. Older dunes, like Tolleston, are found farther inland from Lake Michigan's present shoreline and were formed thousands of years ago when the lake was much larger than it is today. 

In winter, this trail is a popular spot for cross-country skiers looking for a more challenging experience.

Park at either the main lot or at the smaller Tincher Ridge parking lot 50 yards west. Hike for about one mile down Tincher Ridge before falling off into the Rock Shelter Hollow. See many rock outcropping and a large "rock shelter" before climbing out to a high ridge. The trail follows mostly ridges until it drops and crosses Low Gap Loop Road. 

Cross the road and enter the Backcountry Area of Morgan-Monroe State Forest. There is a camping area located near the road. Cross a couple of nice bridges before climbing to the top of Gourley Ridge. Drop again into an isolated valley filled with creeks and pine forest. Depending on the season, wildflowers, wildlife, birds and fungi can be observed. 

Climb out of this hollow and head along a fringe of trees with a logging road. Turn left for Low Gap Loop (Tecumseh Trail turns right) and follow the logging trail to Low Gap Road. Cross the road and continue down/up the gravel road which turns back into another logging trail. 

Follow this trail past Indiana University Hardwood Ecosystem study (look for the tubing and buckets) until it turns to the left. From there, the trail runs just south of the main forest road back to the parking area. Look for pileated woodpeckers on this section. 

Overall, this is a very nice trail with some isolation, especially in the backcountry area.
Do not drink the water! The numerous Hemlock trees in the area release toxins into the water. There are no restrooms or facilities of any kind for miles.

The Dune Succession Trail (Loop 1) at West Beach highlights the four stages of dune development within its one-mile length. The actual trail is only ~0.6 miles long, but the loop totals one mile when the necessary jaunts along the road and West Beach Trail are factored in. From the parking lot, follow the road north, toward the lake and look for the trail to pick up to the west of the bathhouse. 

This scenic, but strenuous, trail includes a climb up 250 stairs for a spectacular view of Lake Michigan and Chicago. Support the restoration effort in the fragile dunes and ponds, or pannes, by remaining on designated trails.

The main trail is not accessible to wheelchairs. However, there is a paved road from the parking lot to the bathhouse that offers views of Lake Michigan that is accessible to wheelchairs. The main parking lot has spots for 596 cars and is open year round.

There are restroom facilities and potable water available year round in the West Beach Contact Station. Seasonal showers, lockers and a lifeguarded beach are available from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day weekend.

Indiana Dunes National Park (formerly national lakeshore) was established to preserve portions of the Indiana Dunes and other areas of scenic, scientific, historic and recreational value. Up to two million annual visitors enjoy the park's 15,000 acres of wetlands, prairies, sand dunes, oak savannas, forests, and historic sites. The park's 15 miles of beaches hug the southern shore of Lake Michigan from Gary, IN, to Michigan City, IN. For more information, visit  nps.gov/indu/index.htm or  facebook.com/IndianaDunesNPS.

This is an easy to access trail that leaves from the French Lick Resort parking lot and traverses through forested hills.  Keep an eye out for other trail users, as this is a mixed use trail allowing those on foot in addition to biking and horseback riding.

Park at either the beach or at the Nature Center. The preferred direction is counter-clockwise. The first half of the hike is on flat to rolling trail in the forest. The footing is good with a mixture of sand and packed dirt. The trail is never crowded, even on summer weekends. 

At the furthest point east, the trail will turn north and climb over a steep vegetated sand dune. Footing is loose sand. Once to the lake, the trail back to the beach Pavilion runs along the beach. The beach is amazingly pristine. Take plenty of water as this hike will take longer than it appears due to the loose sand.

Be aware that the elevation profile for this trail, as well as many trails in Shades and Turkey Run State Parks are very inaccurate due to the small, deep ravines many of the trails pass through. These ravines typically do not show up well on terrain maps.

Trail may be impassible during periods of high water.

This trail features very hazardous and dangerous terrain. It is not recommended for children. Please exercise caution while on the ridgelines.

The trail is rough, rugged, and rutted in places, with a number of steep climbs and descents. Fallen trees, logs, and loose rock may be encountered at any time, as the trail receives minimal maintenance. 

The trail is marked with white and green markers. Some markers can be difficult to locate, especially in places where trees have fallen.

Beginning in the campground, near the entrance to the Horseman's Camp loop, follow the gravel access trail a short distance down to the Adventure Hiking Trail intersection on the right. 

The trail descends approximately one mile toward the Blue River, crossing the Breeden Ridge Trail, before dropping into the river valley and crossing the old Iron Bridge Road. (The trail runs through the bottom lands near the Blue River, and the area can be wet or closed during high water events.)

Following the edge of the Blue River for a mile or so, the trail climbs back up the ridges and crosses the Fire Tower Trail in two locations before descending again toward Fox Hollow, eventually climbing back up the hills for a view of the Blue River, near the trail intersection at Rendezvous Point. Just across the river is the old Stagecoach Campground.

The trail continues across a series of ridges and valleys for about 3 miles and after another descent, the trail climbs once again as it nears IN-462, and crosses that road a short distance from the O'Bannon Woods State Park entrance.

After crossing IN-462, the trail winds through a swampy area, and then once again descends through a rocky segment following a dry creek bed, before climbing again. The trail continues to twist and wind, with a number of shorter climbs and descents before a long climb to the Old Forest Road crossing. It's about 2 miles from crossing to crossing.

From Old Forest Road, the trail drops and climbs again, and joins a horse trail for a short segment along a ridge line. The trail breaks off and continues to wind through the woods before reaching the steep limestone bluffs that overlook Indian Creek far below. The trail follows along the edge of the bluff closely, before reaching the Indian Creek Shelter a short distance later.

From the Indian Creek Shelter, the trail descends and climbs a number of times, through rocky creek beds and up short hills, approximately 3.5 miles before reaching the Old Homestead Shelter.

Another series of short climbs is followed by long descent to the Cold Friday Road crossing, about 1.5 miles from the Old Homestead Shelter. The Cold Friday Road crossing is an excellent place to cache supplies, or leave a vehicle in case of an emergency.

From Cold Friday Road, the trail climbs up a steep rocky hillside, and makes a steep descent into a dry creek bed, before climbing steeply once again up a sharp switchback step. Following along the edge of another ridge, the trail descends and climbs once more, before reaching a long, scenic section that runs along the edge of the bluffs overlooking the Ohio River. The trail joins a horse trail for a short distance before reaching the Ohio River Overlook Shelter. It's about 2.8 miles from Cold Friday to the shelter.

From the Overlook Shelter, the trail makes a twisty mile-long descent toward Potato Run Creek and follows along a steep bank overlooking the creek. The trail crosses Potato Run Creek near the Pioneer Shelter and crosses the paved park road, climbing up a steep bank on the opposite side over a series of water bars.

The trail continues to climb the ridge and twists and winds through a series of short descents and climbs before eventually crossing the Breeden Ridge Trail. After crossing Breeden Ridge, the campground is a short distance away, with the trail joining the gravel access trail the hike began on.

The Rim Trail is one of many trails within Depauw Nature Park. It starts with a tough, steep climb up to the rim of the quarry, then levels out for the remainder of the trail. This particular trail is great for trail running or hiking, but regardless of how you enjoy it, you'll want to take in the views as they are beautiful.  Nearly the entire trail follows the rim of the old rock quarry, so you'll be treated to a expansive vantage point of the whole quarry from anywhere you are.

This is GBP's longest loop; follow the red shield "Perimeter Loop" blazes. Starting near the main parking area, the trail heads north through the forest before reaching a climb; the trail follows a wider trail NW along the lake. The trail turns north to a long section punctuated by switchbacks; a climb brings hikers to one of the park's tallest hills. 

After a descent, cross a bridge and then turn left. Follow along a pond, cross bridges and a short cobblestone section and then meander through the woods. After crossing another bridge, the trail passes over a few undulating bumps and then climbs out to a right turn. 

Here the Perimeter Loop joins the doubletrack dirt Moore Road that is followed for about a mile to a singletrack trail situated along the park's southern boundary. Take in gorgeous views of Stryker Lake before reaching the SW parking lot. The trail continues across the lot and follows short ridges with dips in-between. The trail then straightens out and leads to some switchbacks before ending near the main parking area.

This is a very popular area for mountains bikers. Be aware of your surroundings and of other users on the trail.

Trail 4 can be accessed from a few spots throughout the park. For our hike we took Trail 1 from behind the Spring Mill Inn to reach Trail 4. You can also access the trail from the parking area near the Pioneer Village. 

The trail takes you to many historical elements of the park. The Pioneer Village is a historical recreation of what life was like in this area in the 1800's. Log cabins and the working grist mill our manned by interpreters are open for you to explore. Upon approaching the Pioneer Village, you'll have two choices to continue your hike. One portion of the trail will take you thorough the village, and the other way takes you around the village. NO DOGS are allowed in the village, so plan accordingly. 

Just past the Pioneer Village, you'll pass Hamer Cave and eventually come across the Hamer Pioneer Cemetery. The path follows the back side of the cemetery along the fence. You'll need to work your way around to the front to access the cemetery if you wish to explore there. Be on the look out for grave markers identifying servicemen who fought and died for our country.

After the cemetery, you'll cross through a parking and picnic area and descend a long series of wooden steps taking you down to the creek. From here you can turn right for a very short spurt to Donaldson Cave. Turning left at the bottom of the steps completes the loop and takes you past the Wilson Monument honoring Andrew Wilson an early American ornithologist. The monument was erected in 1866 by George Donaldson, the former land owner.

You'll come across many hills and valleys and will be met with many rock formations that you'll need to work around on this trail. The park map calls this trail "rugged" and it lives up to it's classification.

The B-Line Trail is a rails to trails conversion that offers perfect walking, running, and biking in the middle of downtown Bloomington. With easy access to many other trails and roads, this is one of the best fitness paths in the area.
Entrance to the park in the warmer months is $7 for Indiana residents, and $9 for people out of state.
Bathrooms  at the parking lot are closed during the winter months.

Most people park at either Newby Gulch shelter or the Nature Center for this trail. When parking at the Nature Center, take the 70 Steps Connector down to the bottom of the canyon. Turn left on Trail #1 until Trail #2 branches to the right.

Once on Trail #2, you'll enter Box Canyon, one of the most underrated canyons at Turkey Run. This canyon feels like trekking through a tropical rainforest in the summertime and is worth checking out. The trail climbs a stone staircase carved into the rock and is truly a sight to see. At the top, multiple pathways emerge and it can be difficult to determine which one is the trail. Continue straight, and the trail should become narrow again and bank to the right.

The trail now follows the canyon rim and dips down into the valley where it hugs the rock wall. Eventually you'll come to Gypsy Gulch, another underrated landmark at Turkey Run. The trail continues to hug the wall here, and sometimes a waterfall will form in the middle of the gulch which can be walked behind. After passing the gulch, the trail passes more interesting sandstone cliffs before meeting the Lusk Earth Fill Connector. Turn right and follow Trail #2.

The rest of the trail is pretty flat and traverses forest and a road before passing Canyon Shelter, some picnic areas, and some parking. The trail returns to the rock staircase, completing the loop. This trail is typically less trafficked, making it a nice trail to get away from the crowds at Turkey Run.

A short, fun hike around Spring Mill Lake. Passes by the Nature Center featuring numerous exhibits for people of all ages. The trail itself is easy, but not completely flat, and is less crowded than the rest of the park. The lake is typically infested with turtles in the summertime, and it's easy to spot hundreds of turtles during your hike. This trail is very good for kids and families, and doesn't take very long.
You'll be climbing over rocks through the creek.

Trail skirts the edge of the lake, and is sometimes very narrow. Trail improvements have been made, including stone and wood stairs, and wooden bridges and boardwalks, which can be very slick at times. Several points along the trail offer great views and photo opportunities.

This is a very short trail that is crammed full with landmarks and things to see. I recommend this trail to everyone who pays a visit to Turkey Run State Park and I highly suggest trying this trail in the evening when the canyon gets cold and the crowds go away.

The start of this trail is behind the cabins near the Turkey Run Inn. After passing the cabins, the trail heads down into Turkey Run Hollow. Passing under the Old Highway Bridge, the trail follows the creek around a bend traversing boulders and small caves. About halfway, the trail meets with Trail #7, which is another underused but fantastic trail at Turkey Run. Trail #7 turns left, while Trail #6 continues to the right.

After crossing a bridge, the trail splits and goes to a small beach along Sugar Creek. Swimming is not allowed here, but it is a nice secluded spot to watch the river. Turning to the right, the trail continues by climbing up to Sunset Point, overlooking Sugar Creek from above. Nearby is the Lieber Cabin, which typically houses a few historical exhibits about the park and the area. Trail #6 finishes behind Turkey Run Inn.
Land Manager:  Indiana State Parks

Hesitation Point Trail is an out-and-back trail that ascends from Aynes Loop to the Hesitation Point Overlook. Users will pass the foundation of a CCC cabin at the base of the climb. A steep climb and technical features like multiple rocky sections, logs, large step-downs, bridges, and tight switchbacks make Hesitation Point a very interesting trail. 

The challenging climb brings you to the parking area at the overlook. Be sure to snap a few photos here, especially in the fall, before descending again. Hesitation Point connects with the Walnut Trail, which begins at this parking area, just on the other side of West Gate Rd.
There is one train track crossing that requires bikers to walk around but other than that it is pretty much paved or concrete the whole trail.

description:
Park in the new Sycamore Land Trust lot, the beginning of the trail is clearly marked.  The HHC has constructed a short connector trail from the parking lot to the existing road. 

This was a little mucky during our visit, but short, and once you get back on the old road bed, the footing improves. The trail follows this road bed all the way out to the end of this small peninsula.  The entire length of this route provides lake views including a remarkable 360Â° panorama near the end.

Some residents of the private properties here own dogs, and these canine friends roam freely near their territories. The several I have encountered over time on this trail have all been friendly - so if you respond in kind, all should be well. Remember, always get permission from a dog's owner before petting it, no matter how fluffy it is. Loose dogs in the area make the following rule all the more important:

"Dogs are welcome if leashed at all times. Please be prepared to clean up after your dog." - Sycamore Land Trust general rule.

Christmas Trail is named as such because it looks like a tree laying on its side when viewed on a topographical map. The trail is designed as a set of back and forth dips with some tight turns and fun ups and downs. Toward the front half of the trail, there are two large jumps for mountain bikers. 

The back half of the trail gets a bit more technical with roots and rocks where you'll want to watch your step. This is a really fun part of the Franke Park Trail System.

Christmas Trail ends back at the creek crossing.

The Fire Tower Trail begins just off the parking lot at the base of the old fire tower and runs to the Class A Campground. Look for the wooden entrance gateway. 

The trail starts with a smooth, downhill, curvy segment weaving through a large hardwood forest, with numerous creek crossings and drains to be aware of. As the trail approaches the bluffs overlooking the Blue River, users will encounter more rocky conditions before arriving at a short rock feature that spans a wet area along the steep cliff side. This attention-demanding segment of the trail continues along the edge of the bluff for a short distance before reaching another smoother, easier section. A side trail on the right leads to a scenic overlook.

After a gradual climb to the Iron Bridge Road crossing, the trail continues to twist and turn and descends into a series of curves, toward a wooden bridge and an intersection with the Rocky Ridge Loop. Proceeding up the left fork at the intersection, Fire Tower Trail leads to the campground, the Potato Run Trail and the Breeden Ridge Trail, while a right turn will lead into the Rocky Ridge Loop. 

The trail twists and winds through another section of rocky limestone outcroppings before climbing to the other intersection with the Rocky Ridge Loop. Proceeding left at the fork, Fire Tower Trail continues to climb toward the campground, where water and restrooms are available. 

The Potato Run Trail is accessed by hiking a short distance to the left up one of the campground roads. The entrance is near the ice machine, by the campground gatehouse.
There are no facilities or bathrooms.

Walnut Trail is an advanced trail that will challenge most. You'll traverse narrow singletrack strewn with rocks, logs, roots, and off camber track. Keep an eye out for the expertly built rock bridges. 

Walnut is an out and back, so be aware of returning users. Walnut Trail connects with Hesitation Point Trail at the parking lot and with the north side of Limekiln Trail. 

The two entrances for the expert-only Schooner Trace Trail are also located on the north and south ends of Walnut Trail.

Bobcat features narrow singletrack, rocks, narrow bridges, and a long climb/descent. Starting near Weedpatch Hill (the highest point in Brown County State Park) and dropping deep into the Valley below, the trail features 250 feet of elevation change.

While the entrance near Weedpatch is a show case piece machine-built by Spectrum Trail Designs, the rest of the trail has been hand built to ensure a rugged old school vibe.

This trail is complete. Bobcat Trail now loops back up to the Bobcat Connector .
There is a crossing at Hunt Road at the one mile mark. Hunt Road is a sometimes-busy rural road, so take care when crossing.

The Rocky Ridge Loop joins the Fire Tower Trail in two locations. Traveling downhill from the Fire Tower, the first intersection is just a short distance past the wooden bridge. 

At the signpost where the Fire Tower Trail meets the Rocky Ridge Loop, taking a right at the intersection will lead down Rocky Ridge, toward a rugged, rocky, rooted section, before descending into the neighboring ravine, crossing a typically dry creek bed. After a long climb, the entrance to the Breeden Ridge Trail will be on the right.

Taking the fork to the left, the Fire Tower Trail slowly climbs toward the Class A campground, through a scenic, rocky segment, where large limestone boulders line the edges of the pathway. 

At the next intersection, water and restrooms are available in the campground by taking the left fork, continuing up the Fire Tower Trail. Taking the right fork, following Rocky Ridge, the trail will lead to the Breeden Ridge intersection. 

After a short downhill and crossing a wooden bridge, the trail begins a long rolling descent through the woods. Part way down the trail, a fork to the left will lead to the Breeden Ridge Trail. Further down the trail, after a series of twists and turns, the trail transitions into a rocky and rooted section, following along the edge of a steep-sided ravine. After crossing a typically dry creek bed, the trail continues a rough, rugged and sometimes narrow climb. 

Watch for the rock ramp just when it almost seems like the trail has disappeared. Continue up a rocky climb, over a bridge and through the woods. A left turn at the trail intersection will return to the Fire Tower after a long, mostly uphill climb. A right turn will lead back to the campground.

Pahoka Adventure is a two-way trail that starts at the middle of the Chute and ends at the Oka Run close to the Oka Run Creek crossing. It's a bit more challenging than Walnut or Oka Run. You'll find some short steep sections and a roller coaster section, built by and for the mountain biking community

Hikers will also find some narrow singletrack winding up-and-down and along the side of the hills. This trail is a work in progress, so be aware of new bike-specific features being added. Plans are to double the length in late 2017.

There are several parking areas along this trail so it can be access easily along the route. There are also some neighboring trails on either end of the trail, that while shorter may be something else to explore.

This short yet intense trail starts in the Scout Ridge campground behind the large shelter-house. 

The trail follows the side of the ridge briefly before dropping into a rugged hollow. Following a creek bed, the trail becomes tricky at times due to rocks and water. After crossing a wooden bridge, the trail starts climbing, passing through a rocky area before ending back at the shelter-house. 

Don't be fooled by the short length of this trail. It is chock full of interesting sights and challenging natural features!

This is a portion of a 1.8 mile loop trail around the JI Case Wetland and through part of Hawthorn Park in Vigo County, Indiana. It is mostly flat, with a mix of surfaces including gravel, blacktop road, grass, and trail.

Look for the entrance gates to the trail almost opposite the road to the Fire Tower Lookout parking lot, near the front gatehouse.

The Group Camp Trail begins by weaving through the fallen pines, with poison ivy all along the edges. The hand-cut trail follows along the edge of a gentle ridge, past the raspberries and log hops, before crossing a horse trail. 

After crossing the horse trail, the Group Camp Trail begins to descend into a rugged, rocky, challenging section that follows along the edge of a deep ravine. The trail makes a turn just after a dry creek crossing, crosses a cobblestone minefield and continues along the ravine, past many limestone outcroppings, through a series of switchbacks and along a rocky, rooted segment, before reaching the Group Camp area. 

The trail winds through the woods, through a series of rollers around the Group Camp, before ending at the paved road. The entrance to the Potato Run Trail is just across the road.
Expect tight switchbacks along the way.

The Yellow Trail is the simplest and shortest loop trail on the property. Going past several creek crossings, the cabins, and ending at the main trailhead, it gives you a quick tour of the grounds before putting you back into arm's reach of the other camp trails. This trail is well marked, not difficult, and comprised of a soft-dirt tread, making it a great trail for folks of all ages.

Eventually you'll come across a valley on the right which will seasonally feature a waterfall. Passing the waterfall and a sitting area, the trail rejoins the connector to the campground.

Cross the access road north of the Beginner Loop and hang a right where the singletrack forks. This short trail is reminiscent of a pump track for bikes with rolling jumps and banked turns. Finish up at the gravel multi-use path, or hang a right to catch some more singletrack. This area to the right is an in-progress trail.
Connects trail given various names Top of the Rock Trail to Dry Fork Loop. Very steep and erosion prone though recently reopened and maintained.
No bathrooms.

Start at the parking lot by the Dam, where there is ample parking. Visitors can go either right or left, but heading to the right seems to be the easier way to start. 

The trail is pretty easy. There are some ups and downs but not much elevation change as the trail leads around Ogle Lake. After just over a mile, you'll find yourself returning back to the parking area that you left from.

Eagle Creek Park does an amazing job of maintaining their trails and marking them clearly!

Starting near the 56th Street entrance and moving to the east, the trail takes you toward the Indianapolis Rowing Club HQ. From there, you traverse a small peninsula before moving back into the woods and passing the Earth Discovery Center (a wonderful stop of educational opportunities and exploration!) From there, the trail takes you toward the marina. 

The next part of the trail is really exciting with a modestly steep drop in elevation before you head out on a narrow strip of land that surrounds a bird sanctuary. Lots of people like to hang out on this strip of land to fish. Sometimes the water level is so high that the southern strip of land can be nearly submerged. Once you complete the loop around the Bird Sanctuary, the trail climbs in elevation to the top of a BEAUTIFUL overlook through a mixture of coniferous and deciduous trees. at this point, you start to turn to the southeast and head toward the 71st Street entrance. At this gate, there is a restroom should you need a break. 

From here, the trail takes you along the fitness trail (large/wide/flat) before swinging by the Ornithology Center. Stop by to take a look at the gorgeous hawks! Then, the trail takes you to Lily Lake (great picnic spot) with another restroom opportunity. Moving south, you'll cross 62nd Street and head toward the ice skating pond. Just south of the pond, you'll go back into a deeper wooded area near the main road that runs north-south through the park (Eagle Creek Parkway). The trail ends at the parking lot where you began (and another restroom facility).

This is an easy trail with interpretive stops along the way. Pick up the Interpretive Guide brochure at the trailhead. There are plenty of benches along the way to rest or take a break. You'll even make your way through an area that was an old homestead and have the opportunity to see where there was a well in days of yore. At the end of the trail, be sure to take a seat near the nature center to enjoy the many beautiful species of birds.

The trail begins on a ridge-top fire access road and then veers off the road as a singletrack through the woods. The trail parallels a rock-bottomed stream for a while and then continues through the stream channel to a natural rock shelter. 

A singletrack switchbacks up from the stream bottom and passes a small forest pond that's a great place to see frogs and the occasional turtle. At the trail junction, turn left to complete the 3.3 mile Rock Shelter Loop or turn right to continue on the 10-mile Low Gap Trail. The singletrack merges onto another fire access road that returns to the trailhead parking area.

Since part of the trail uses the creek bed, it may be under water after heavy rains.

This trail starts out at the Millennium Grove Picnic Area near the Camp Glen and equine portions of the park. This is a multi-use trail for both bikes and those on foot. The trail moves through a variety of vegetation including dense wooded areas, open prairie grasses, and wetlands. Depending on time of year, you'll see plenty of wildflowers, cattails and other vegetation throughout the hike. 

The trail switches back and forth and includes many small streams. It is very well maintained with some signage and bridges over the streams. Bikes on this trail are expected to ride one-way while hikers can go either direction. If you take the trailhead to the left from the parking area, you'll be hiking into the bike traffic and will be able to see them coming towards you. The other direction will have the bikes coming up behind you.  As Ft. Harrison was formerly an army base, you'll also see some large concrete structures and footings from building long gone that remind you of the historical significance of the area.

There are several drop off parking areas along the trail so you can hike it in sections. The Falcon Guide guide "Hiking Indiana" has good information on seven trail segments and parking areas at each end of the segments along with good information about each segment.

The Long Lake Trail (Loop 3) is a moderate trail that starts in an area that was sand mined in the 1920s. If you want to hike this loop by itself from the main trailhead, the total round-trip distance is 2.4 miles. You'll start and end the hike using a portion of the West Beach Trail. 

The footing is mainly loose sand. This area is being restored as an oak savanna and is a great place to see prickly pear cactus. The trail follows along Long Lake and then heads into the dunes. There is a great view of long lake after the initial climb. After crossing the entrance road, the trail winds through the undulating dunes and then has a steep climb down an exposed dune to the picnic area.

The trail is not accessible to wheelchairs. However, there is a paved road from the parking lot to the bathhouse that offers views of Lake Michigan that is accessible to wheelchairs. The main parking lot has spots for 596 cars and is open year round. 

There are restroom facilities and potable water available year round in the West Beach Contact Station. Seasonal showers, lockers and a beach (with lifeguards) are available in the summer. 

Indiana Dunes National Park (formerly national lakeshore) was established to preserve portions of the Indiana Dunes and other areas of scenic, scientific, historic and recreational value. Up to two million annual visitors enjoy the park's 15,000 acres of wetlands, prairies, sand dunes, oak savannas, forests, and historic sites. The park's 15 miles of beaches hug the southern shore of Lake Michigan from Gary, IN, to Michigan City, IN. For more information, visit  nps.gov/indu/index.htm or  facebook.com/IndianaDunesNPS.

This trail features a wooded hike, one larger yet short hill climb, and a secluded field that is quiet and calming. The trail is very well-marked, and you can connect to several other trails for a variety of loops if you don't want to take the trail as an out-and-back.
Wear blaze orange during posted deer hunting seasons.

Trail 5 starts and ends at the parking lot near the campground in the Brown County State Park. It connects to Trail 4. This trail can be a loop if combining with with other trails, or it can be out-and-back if you're wanting a short but still rugged hike. 

About halfway through Trail 5, you'll see a sign that points you one of two directions: to Trail 4 or to continue with 5. We continued and did the loop at the end. This is a great area for those who like seclusion; it was a grown up area that had us feeling like we were deep into the forest. If you're just going down Trail 5, there are about 100 stairs, if you're going down and back up, get ready for 200! That's why this trail is rated Difficult, even though the distance is just about 1 mile. 

Depending on the water levels, you'll pass through the creek a few times. Pick up an interpretive brochure as there are numbered stops along the way to learn about the trail and species that inhabit it, including the Yellowwood tree!
There are several sets of stairs.

This trail is heavily wooded with lots of roots and rocks. The trail begins at the Trail 1 Parking Lot and follows an existing gravel road before turning to the left and gradually descending into the Fourteenmile Creek valley. It then meanders through dense floodplain forest before climbing up the valley wall to wind along rock outcrops. A lower portion of the trail offers scenic views of Fourteenmile Creek before climbing again as it returns to the parking lot. Spring wildflowers along portions of this trail will treat hikers to stunning displays. Wildlife, songbirds, and birds of prey may be seen along this trail.

The trail to the backpacker's campground wanders through the woods and across multiple creeks for several miles before depositing you near the river at the campground. The end of the trail has nice sites, water, a privy, and firewood ($5 honor system).  Itâs hardly ever full even on busy weekends, and the raccoons arenât nearly as active as they are at the main campground.
Parking is accessed at any of the intersecting trails or at the Visitor Center.

This trail starts out easy enough, but the next thing you know, you're climbing up a rock ravine in Falls Canyon with water running through it. At the end of the trail, you'll by hiking up stairs, then down again on narrow trails along a cliff, followed by one more ascent of another set of stairs.

This trail is a large loop that will take you from the parking lot to Wolf Cave. It then meanders its way back to the parking lot. There are many sinkholes along the trail, and visitors might want to stop to read the informational board that describes how sinkholes were formed, as you'll be able to put that information to immediate use. The trail is a double wide trail all the way around the loop. After leaving the cave area, the trail takes you along a creek the flows on hard bedrock.

The Monon Rail Trail stretches from the town of Westfield in the north, head through Carmel and Broad Ripple, and goes by by the Indiana State Fairgrounds before intersecting with the Indianapolis Cultural Trail on the east end of Massachusetts Avenue (Mass Ave).

This is a multi-use trail in Evansville that follows along the Ohio River and Pigeon Creek. The 10-foot wide paved trail is very popular along the Ohio and can be teeming with people on a warm day.  The northern section thins out as it heads into quiet, rolling hills and follows the flood levy along Pigeon Creek.  There are many playgrounds, sitting areas, and art displays along this path.

The official Benton Dam loop is officially measured at 1.3 miles, but there's a few spots you can either double back, or continue on, so the length varies a tiny bit based on your hiking style. The loop provides fantastic opportunities for wildlife observation, photography, and fishing. Parking is limited to summer, but visitors can park year-round at the adjacent Benton Spillway.

Find more info, including all of River Preserve Park's access sites and amenities at:  elkhartcountyparks.org/destâ¦
A nice hike through a Natural Area south of Terre Haute.

This is the Memorial Loop Trail at Whitewater Memorial State Park. This park is Indiana's 16th state park and is dedicated to the men and women who served in World War II. The trail is easily accessed from many locations and makes a complete loop while it meanders through the park. For our hike, we accessed it from the parking area near Shelter 2. Other good places to access this trail with plenty of parking is at the boat launch or picnic shelter 3. 

This trail will take you up hills and into valleys/ravines as you explore part of the eastern shoreline of Whitewater Lake. Look for waterfowl as well as frogs and turtles who make the lake their home. This trail will take you past the naturalist cabin where you can enjoy many interpretive programs from Memorial Day through Labor Day. It will also cross paths with the horse trail a number of times. Be on the lookout for deer, raccoon, and other wildlife during your trek. In the spring many wildflowers blanket the area which makes for a beautiful and enjoyable hike.

The Cliff Dweller Trail is a challenging loop, following part of the Adventure Trail along Potato Run. Originally built as a hiking trail, the trail is now multi-use.

The trail begins at the Pioneer Shelter and crosses Potato Run Creek, which is usually dry. Follow along Potato Run and climb up, following along the steep-sided bank overlooking Potato Run Creek. 

The Cliff Dweller Trail forks off to the left after a rugged climb, but local hikers typically tie Cliff Dweller into a hike up to the Ohio River Overlook Shelter (AKA Lloyd's Cabin), on The Adventure Hiking Trail Loop for a great view of the Ohio River, before returning to the trail intersection.

The descent from the intersection crosses a number of rocky ravines before dropping through the cedars. Use caution on the descent, as the trail drops off sharply over a rocky outcropping, followed by a hard left turn. The trail then follows along a rocky creek bed, climbing and descending another rocky outcropping before returning to the Potato Run crossing. Follow the trail up the hill, back to Pioneer Cabin.

Beginning at the intersection with Rocky Ridge Loop, Breeden Ridge is one of O'Bannon Woods State Park's newest trails. It joins with the new Potato Run Trail near the Nature Center.

Breeden Ridge begins with a classic hand-built segment leading into a rocky section with a number of optional lines. Past the rocks, the new machine built trail begins, with a rolling climb to the top of Breeden Ridge. A stair-step segment through the rocks leads toward the top of the ridge.

Once at the top of the ridge, the trail twists, and winds, with a number of berms and rollers, and descends through a challenging, rocky staircase toward more berms, rollers, and rock features. The trail climbs toward a small woodland pond--the highest point on the trail. From the pond, a series of twisting turns leads into some mountain biking features, before reaching a horse trail crossing.

Past the ridge line horse crossing, the trail begins to descend toward Potato Run, with another series of features popular with mountain bikers, as it drops down into the valley. 

Use caution while approaching the horse trails, and yield to horseback riders, if present.

With a twisting climb up the other side of the creek, the trail begins to level out, with another series of bike features, before joining the Potato Run Trail.

A left at the trail junction will return the user up Potato Run toward the campground while a right turn will allow the user to continue toward the bottom of the Group Camp Trail.
"Dogs are welcome if leashed at all times. Please be prepared to clean up after your dog." - Sycamore Land Trust general rule.
State park entrance fee paid at either gate entering.
This is a dirt trail that crosses over Cool Creek. It is a mostly flat trail with a few spots of sand and roots. At the start of the hike, there is a natural well that you can get water from.

Trail 4 is a little wider than most trails in the park, with one steep uphill/downhill depending on where you start. It begins by the campground and is a 2.3 mile out-and-back trail, or you can use part of Trail 5 to make it a loop (to avoid lots of stairs, start at Trail 5). 

Trail 4 connects to Trail 7 and Trail 5 and takes you to Ogle Lake. You can even stop and rest at an overlook for Ogle Lake mid-way through Trail 4. The trail has firm ground and is generally flat except for one steep incline/decline depending on the direction you hike. Give yourself about an hour to hike this one way.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Pokagon State Park

If you want to stop at the Lower Shelter House for a quick sit-down or bathroom break, look for a trail by the stone fireplace - it'll take you down to an old road that leads to the Lower Shelter House.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Potato Creek State Park

There is (well, when we visited there was) a porta potty past the barn. On the barn's side are some informative signs.

Importantly, there are at least two friendly loose dogs in the area. As such, based on a sign on the barn as well, not even leashed dogs are allowed - though the exception is guide dogs. I assume this is to protect the loose dogs from less friendly visitors, and official guide dogs are truly well-trained and therefore it makes sense (to me) to allow 'em. I'll edit this later if this changes. And not to worry, the loose dogs are not always there, but they are always friendly. Downright polite. As far as I've experienced.

Park on the West side of the park at the Mountain Biking Parking lot. 

Follow the green arrows on the trail markers for a leisurely hike with few significant obstacles.
Wilderness Areaâlimited cell signal, if any.

This short, wheelchair accessible, paved trail features the Calumet Dunes ridge that formed at what once was the edge of the lake over 6,000 years ago. Ancient Lake Chicago, precursor to Lake Michigan, was once much larger. The lake slowly receded forming three major parallel dune ridges: Glenwood (640' above sea level), Calumet (620' above sea level) and Tolleston (605' above sea level). The current lake level is approximately 580' above sea level. U.S. Highway 12 follows the high ground of the Tolleston Dunes ridge in this area, just north of the trail.

The paved parking lot holds 35 cars. It is located at the intersection U.S. Highway 12 and Kemil Road (East State Park Road 300E). This is the location of the old visitor center. Use insect repellent, wear long sleeves, and tuck long pants into socks to avoid ticks and poison ivy.

Twin Lakes Trail consists of larger sections of singletrack joined by a couple of fire lanes. The ever-changing topography makes it one of the system's best trails. There's also a hand-built, bench-cut ascent to look out for with some features that are tailored for mountain bikers, as this is a multi-use trail.

This trailhead begins across the street from the swimming pool parking lot.  In the summertime, the pool is a great spot to cool down after a hot hike. There is a kiosk and a few picnic tables in the shade nearby, also. You have to begin on this trail to reach other parts of the trail system. 

At the start of the trail, take a left to head north and begin the loop clockwise. The trail begins with a climb, but the grades are not too terrible. Once at the top of the bluff, this trail winds through the forest with relatively little elevation change.  There's nothing terribly technical about this trail, but keep your eyes peeled for evidence of the karst landscape (hint: sinkholes!).  Some of them are right along the trail.

Start at the Ranger Station right off of 446, park behind it. From there, the trailhead is easy to see. You go about .1 miles before having to decide to go right or left. Both options are equally as pleasant. Hikers can stay on the loop going either direction. There are maps posted at every intersection, making navigation easy. This is a pretty easy trail and the route is fairly popular with locals. There are some ups and downs, but overall this loop can be done by about anybody.

This is also a biking trail so be alert and respectful of other users.

This is a great easy trail with gently rolling terrain offer nice downhills and a few uphills. There aren't any major obstacles or rocky sections. 

This trail sees plenty of two way traffic, and is also used by bikers.
Tip: If you don't want to climb up nearly 200 stairs at the end of your hike, begin at the NW trailhead where Trail 1 and Trail 2 merge.

Trail 2 is a really nice, flat trail that runs through mature forest and wetlands. It can be easily accessed from the Nature Center, campground, or by parking at the Wilson Shelter. On the east and west ends, the trail crosses the Great Marsh via a boardwalk. The trail is often used in the winter for cross country skiing.

Hikers looking for a long hike can combine Trail 2 with Trail 10 for a great loop of the park.
About 1.5 miles in, you can get off trail and see Hesitation Point, so bring your cameras!

The Bailly Homestead / Chellberg Farm Trail, along with the  Little Calumet River / Mnok Prairie Trail and Bailly Cemetery Trail, reveal the rich natural diversity that has drawn people to this area for over 10,000 years. Hike through a forest dominated by maple, beech, basswood, and oak trees. Follow a stretch of the Little Calumet River, once a critical transportation route for early regional travelers, and explore the recently restored Mnok Prairie for a glimmer of the vast stretches of pre-settlement grasslands. 

Visit the Bailly Homestead and Chellberg Farm to glimpse how families lived and farmed in Northwest Indiana. 

The Bailly Homestead, a National Historic Landmark (1962), was the home of Honore Gratien Joseph Bailly de Messein (1774 - 1835). Bailly played a role in the development of the Calumet Region of northern Indiana. He was an independent trader in the extensive fur-trading network that spread from Montreal to Louisiana, and ultimately to Europe. Joseph Bailly was one of the earliest settlers in northern Indiana. In 1822, Bailly set up his fur trading post at the crossroads of several important trails. The Bailly Homestead complex is the last remaining site of its nature in the Calumet Region.

In the 1870s, Swedish immigrants Anders and Johanna "Kjellberg" bought 80 acres to establish a modest family farm. They were the first of three generations of the Chellberg Family to make their living here. In the 1930s, the Chellbergs started to tap the many maple trees on their property for the production of maple syrup.

The Annual Maple Sugar Time event in March (first 2 weekends) features the evolution of "maple sugaring" in Northwest Indiana from an early American Indian method, to the pioneer method of boiling sap in open iron kettles, to the relatively modern commercial method of producing syrup. Indiana Dunes National Park is the only National Park Service location that makes maple syrup.

There are 3 covered picnic shelters near the parking lot that are wheelchair accessible. The shelters are reservable at recreation.gov starting six months in advance of the desired use date. Cooking fires at the picnic shelters are permitted in the provided grills or an approved carry-in grill. An approved grill is a noncombustible container with an enclosed bottom and enclosed sides with a minimum depth of 2 inches. Charcoal must be cooled and safely disposed of in a noncombustible container or removed from the area.

Trail 4 runs from the campground to the beach and climbs over the 192 foot tall Mt. Tom using stairs and boardwalks. The the top of Mt. Tom is above the tree canopy and affords incredible views in several directions.
The Camp Creek Trail has lots of twists and turns. It does overlap or go right next to several of the other trails a couple times so use the Hiking Project mobile app to help find your way.

The trail starts from the Delaware Lake parking lot and follows Fall Creek for about 1.1 miles. A portion of the trail is on an elevated boardwalk overlooking the river. Halfway through, is a small hill with a staircase to climb. There is a picnic table at the top where you can stop and enjoy the view of the creek and the forest. 

The trail runs parallel to the paved Harrison Trace Trail, but it is not visible for most of the hike. The trail ends near the eastern portion of the park where it joins the Harrison Trace Trail. Here you have the option of hiking on the paved Harrison Trace Trail or continuing through the woods along the Camp Creek Trail.
The Mason Ridge Trail bypasses the west side of the Low Gap Backcountry Trail that was being worked on throughout 2017. Along the way, enjoy a peaceful forested trail that's relatively flat.
The portion of Trail 3 leading to Rose Island is paved but extremely steep.

The Peninsula trail is well signed and easy to follow, particularly for a wilderness area trail. The trail initially follows a very rutted and often muddy horse trail that can be uneven even in the wintertime when the previous season's muddy furrows have frozen over. Fortunately, several of the most heavily disturbed sections of trail have been bypassed singletrack that is designated with "hiking" signs.

Because the trails follows along a gentle ridge, it isn't very strenuous, especially compared to the nearby Pate Hollows trails. Eventually, the trail turns into all singletrack with an awesome hillside overlook of the lake before it descends more steeply toward the edge of the peninsula.

Along the final leg, the trail is shored up by timbers to help combat the swampiness. The last descent brings hikers to the rocky shoreline of Lake Monroe where some nearby lakeside houses are visible. This is a great spot to enjoy lunch or a swim before heading back to the trailhead.

This rail trail links several cities and other rail trails together. The western trailhead is at the Oak Ridge Prairie County Park at 301 South Colfax Street in Griffith, IN. The trail crosses over Lake George on its way into Hobart.

The eastern end of the Oak Savannah Trail connects to the Prairie Duneland Trail, which runs all the way to Porter / Chesterton.

This trail starts at the Trail 8 Trailhead, Parking, and Picnic Area. From here, the trail meanders for a short length before encountering a water crossing nearly first thing. After the crossing, continue along the canyon. Toward the end, the trail gets rough and rocky. If it is wet, those rocks can be incredibly slick, so be careful. The end of the trail greets you with another creek crossing before reaching the junction with Trail 2.

This is a great multi-use trail. It is a gravel track with some creek crossings. The Buffalo Trace (Indiana's first super-highway circa 1800) passes along this trail and is visible at times. A couple of old spring houses can still be seen, and a small cavern is found just off trail a short distance.

In recent years a beaver has dammed up French Lick Creek, which has caused the normally shallow creek crossing to widen and deepen.
There is a port-a-potty located in the parking lot at the start/finish line.
Land Manager:  Indy Parks and Recreation

The Marott Park Main Loop has some decent hill climbs on the trail. There are multiple other trails out here as well if you want to extend your hike. The park is dog friendly, and there is access to the river in the summer, allowing hikers to cross over to the other trails on the other side.

This is a short, 3-mile singletrack with a slightly wider section in middle.  It follows a creek and the Wabash river for a bit.  The hardwood forest really comes alive with colors in the fall.  Also connects to the Wabash Heritage Trail - Northern Portion via a creek crossing (no bridge).

This started as a bike trail and is used by bikers, walkers and runners alike.  Be aware of all of these while on the trail.  Also, cross country meets are held here, so be aware of sections that might be closed or blocked during cross country season.

If you are looking for a rugged trail, then check out Trail 10! With a couple of steep uphill climbs and descents along washed out terrain, this 2.2-mile trail is scenic and secluded, while also offering a bit of a challenge. One of the more difficult trails in the state park, this trail will definitely get you winded in some spots, but isnât so tough that you have to be an expert to complete it. 

It starts at the firetower, which also is something fun to do in the park (if you can make the climb up the stairs, the view from the 90-foot structure is worth it). 

After hitting the trail, you'll hike along a wide, straight path before meeting a split in the trail. Stay to the left to continue your hike. Next, youâll approach a steep descent, which levels out at the bottom. A couple more small ascents and descents, and youâll discover a little pond about one mile in. Shortly after, the trail will become more washed out as you encounter a steep descent into the trail basin. 

At your lowest point, around 1.3 miles in, youâll cross a creek bed before beginning your ascent out. Get ready for a pretty tough uphill climb for a couple tenths of a mile before the trail flattens out. Then, itâs time to climb again until you reach the Shelter House at mile 1.9. Catch your breath and take a break before wrapping up the trail with one more moderate climb that will take you back to the initial split. Once there, itâs smooth sailing until you reach the end.

The trail along the ridge is nice rolling terrain with no real scenic overlooks. The fall colors will make up for the lack of the overlooks if you happen to be visiting in September-October. The right timing here will give you awesome colors to enjoy.

This trail is open for mountain biking and horse riding, so it's a good idea to keep your eyes and ears open for other trail users. The south parking area is rather small but the north parking will handle plenty of cars and those with horse trailers. The published trail info warns about rattlesnakes but we didn't see any on our outing.

This is an easy hike around the private lake at the Mount. The trail is well-marked and kept clear of trees. There are some areas with significant roots to watch out for, but its a fun trail and not too long.
Avoid this trail if its rained in the past 2-3 day as very much as the hill becomes too slick and soft.

Park in the small area along the north side of the road then follow the forest road north. You'll cross 
two gas pipeline cuts in the first half mile, neither particularly offensive. Keep an eye out for the USFS signs on the opposite side of each cut. 

The trail then rolls along the ridge to the "peak". You'll find some dinner table sized rocks, just past the peak on the left (south) side of the trail. These are the Hominy Mortars, rumored to be a place where natives ground corn, but likely just some neat holes in the rocks. Turn around and follow the trail back for a 3.5+/- mile total. Note the long views are going to be primarily seasonal while the leaves are down. 

This is the link to the USFS pamphlet, which also describes the south section of the trail.
There is parking at the activities center and at a cafe along the trail about 0.4 miles north of the activities center.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Morgan-Monroe State Forest

This trail winds around Lake Lincoln, following the shoreline and crossing the dam. It's mostly a dirt trail and, given its elevation relative to the lake, can get fairly muddy in the wetter months. That said, the park has built elevated wood platforms through the worst of it, making it manageable even in the muddiest conditions. Along the back end, there are a few steep grades for only a few feet, but it may be enough to make it difficult for some people. 

One of the highlights of the trail is that it is the access trail to the Fire Tower Trail. The fire tower is one of the highest point in the surrounding counties, allowing you to see for miles in every direction and providing some excellent views. Taking this trail will add some distance and increase the difficulty due to much steeper grades and several flights of stairs up the tower, but it is quite worth it.
From the Battleground terminus to Fort Ouiatenon, it is 13.8 miles.
All visitors in the field must wear fluorescent orange hat or vest during allowed deer and turkey hunting seasons.  The seasons are shortened durations from the state-defined seasons.

Starting at the Abe Martin Lodge, this trail is relatively flat with only a couple of moderate climbs and descents. It also passes by the amphitheater and Saddle Barn!

After beginning the trail near the Abe Martin Lodge, you'll hike down a few stairs before reaching the beautiful State Park amphitheater. Shortly after, you'll start your descent toward the Saddle Barn. Upon reaching a T in the trail, take a left to continue your hike downward. Another set of stairs and you bottom out at the Saddle Barn, where you can pop over for a closer look at the horses if you like. 

Follow the signs across the gravel road, a grassy area, and the paved road before picking the dirt trail back up. Head into the woods again for a slow, steady ascent. The trail will then flatten out a bit before making its descent into the valley. Climb up a flight of stairs and the trail will level out again, offering scenic views of the valley below. 

Youâll then cross a wooden bridge over a creek about 1 mile in. Now, itâs time to begin your ascent to the top. During this time, Trail 3 will intersect with Trail 2 around the 1.3-mile mark. Keep heading up toward the Lodge, climb a few more stairs, and then youâre done!

A great trail for anyone, especially families, Trail 3 is easy with plenty of things to check out and discover along the way, including the Abe Martin Lodge, the amphitheater, and the Saddle Barn!
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Charlestown State Park

This trail begins at the first intersection with the Camp Glenn Trail.  Keep to the left to follow it back to the Camp Glenn Trail, and then use the Camp Glenn Trail to return to the parking lot.

This trail has more elevation change and more rocks, roots, and log crossings.  It is also longer than Camp Glenn, so it will take more fitness to complete this one.  The trail itself also tends to be a little bit narrower.

The north-facing slope near Snake Creek tends to stay wet for a long time. If the Snake Creek area is wet, please use the Lawrence Creek Connector to exit to the road and bypass this section.

There are also a couple of longer downhill sections on this trail.

This trail starts off deceptively easy beginning on a paved surface, but quickly turns the corner and descends to the creek far below. The surface is new, but the path is steep and causes a nice leg burn. This short leg leads to the bridge to Rose Island, the abandoned ruins of an old amusement park that was destroyed in the 1937 flood. Finishing the loop, the paved trail is now mostly singletrack. Itâs very rough and this section is not suitable for strollers or people with footing issues. It works it way along the creek for a while before beginning the climb back up through the woods and to the parking lot. Overall, the trail is a great hike.
There are facilities at the Burdette trailhead with drink machines and public restrooms.
This is a rail trail that's paved, nice and level, and has good shade.
This trail departs from the lake to work deeper into the woods and make a larger loop. It is more wooded and quiet making for a pleasant hike.

The trail begins around Endris Lodge or Flatwoods Shelter. There are a few creek crossings with wooden footbridges, and there are some good views of Silver Creek during the first 0.75 miles of the trail. The trail alternates from dense hardwood forest to open fields. There are numerous side trails during the entire duration of the hike, mostly west of the parking lot. The trail passes a golf course and a disc golf course.

Like the other trails at Versailles State Park, Grandview Loop can done in either direction.  There are rocks and rugged parts, but this trail is characterized by its climbs and its descents.

On hot summer days, you'll notice that the trail can be breezy and comfortable on top of the bluffs, yet stifling in the valleys.  It will make you want to work hard to find the breeze again.
Land Manager:  Indiana State Parks

This trail circles upland woods and ravines along the eastern bluff of Laughery Valley, featuring oak, hickory, maple, beech, tulip poplar, black walnut, and other native trees. Look for limestone sinkholes along the way. 

The trail can be accessed from below, from the Old Fire Tower Road, or from near the Oak Grove Picnic Area. Most of the trail is on rocks, so watch out if it's wet because the rocks are slick.

From the west lot 
Follow the blue/green arrows to the road. Hike back on the paved trail and over the river. Take the first left. Descend into the darkside.

 From the East Lot 
Hike to the South side of the parking lot and turn right (West) on the paved trail.

If the barrier is up 
Hike through the gate, take a right, and hike the Darkside backwards. Turn around and go forward when you reach the River. Follow the arrows back.

With one trailhead conveniently located in the campground near Site 17, this trail is easily accessed if you are camping at the park. Descending a wooded ravine, the trail eventually comes to a platform overlooking Fourteenmile Creek. Winding back up the hillside, the trail ends where it started, so itâs a short hike back to your campsite. Non-campers can enjoy this trail by parking in the overflow lot and hiking the 0.3-mile leg to the main loop.
There are no restrooms or potable water at the trailhead.

Trail 6 is only around a half mile long per the park map, but feels much longer. This trail weaves along the top of the bluff line and offers stunning winter views of the whole valley. The three waterfalls along the way make this a gem of the trail system here. Note that the trail does have a lot of larger rocks and roots in it, but with no major elevation changes, it is very easy. This trail does NOT connect to Trail 5 at the falls as it may appear.

The Taylor Ridge Trail #9 Extension takes visitors through beautiful drainages and atop steep ridges to eventually connect with the Taylor Ridge Trail #9. Along the way, its well-maintained tread allows you to worry less about tripping over obstacles and focus your attention on soaking up your surroundings. 

To start this trail, park at Ogle Lake and follow the Ogle Lake Trail #7 along its southern rim. In just a few short steps, take a right at the fork and follow the trail as it leaves the lake to climb steeply up a ridgeline. Enjoy feelings of accomplishment atop the ridge before descending sharply down the backside to a drainage below. You'll re-create this sequence over the next ridgeline and adjacent drainage before climbing out of the drainage and ending the trail at the junction with the Taylor Ridge Trail #9. From here, you can either return the way you came or enjoy a loop around the Taylor Ridge Trail #9 for more gorgeous woodland views and true serenity.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Turkey Run State Park

Red Mill County Park is 160 acres in size and located in the glacier moraine leftover from the last ice age. The park has really nice mature forests covering the hilly terrain. Round Lake serves as the headwaters of the Little Calumet River. All the trails are wide with good footing. There are ample picnic tables and benches throughout the park. 

The trail runs through the Little Calumet Headwaters State Dedicated Nature Preserve. The trees are really fantastic and look like old growth in some spots. Start the trail from the main parking lot. It's paved from the parking lot to the Environmental Education Center building and packed dirt with leaf litter afterwards. This trail is easy to follow as it appears to have been used by vehicles before it became a nature preserve.

Trail 4 begins at same parking lot as Trail 3. Beginning on gently rolling land, this trail soon begins to descend into mixed hardwood forests as it follows tributaries of Fourteenmile Creek. At about the halfway point, hikers will see commanding views of Fourteenmile Creek from a bluff more than 100 feet above the water. High quality woodlands and striking wildflower displays are found on this trail. Trail surface varies from dirt singletrack with roots and rocks to century old roadbed.

This trail is the second left off of Shadow Run at the apex of the first big switchback (if hiking Shadow Run clockwise).  It begins with a good bit of exposure high on the bluff above Laughery Creek.  It has several rocky sections before it heads into the forest on its way towards Center Loop.

Keep your eyes peeled for cool rock work (there is a great bench for two constructed from rock).
The trail begins about midway down the road in the horseman's campground and comes back to the same campground at the north end.
This is an easier hike that is mostly level-ish and fairly wide, with gravel. Going south from the top is mostly downhill.

Parking is available across the road from the fire tower. No restrooms, no water, spotty cell service - plan ahead

The eastern end of Trail 18 begins where it intersects near the midpoint of Hickory Ridge Trail 20, near the town of Maumee, IN. 

It heads generally west until shortly after it crosses N. County Road 1460 W., where it turns to the south to intersect with Hickory Ridge Trail 4. There are a couple steeper grades (both up and down) near its western terminus at Hickory Ridge Trail 4.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.
This wide dirt path heads back to the nearby road and is just a nice hike in the woods. The trail is flat and simple, nothing really special, just a quiet path.

This short loop of the Glidewell Trail winds through dense hardwood forests out to a small 2000-year-old Native American mound around the 1.0 mile mark. After crossing the mound, the trail passes a small pond on the farthest point of the trail. The long loop branches to the right at the pond, while the short loop branches to the left.

Continuing on the short loop, the trail navigates some isolated cropland before reentering the forest. At a T in the trail, turn left to go back to the parking lot. The remainder of the trail is along a gravel road until the parking lot.
Close to the city and two of the best coffee shops around!
No restrooms, no water, spotty cell service.
Land Manager:  Indiana State Parks
On this trail, you'll quickly depart the high fields and get out into the woods and along a quiet creek. This short trail is shady and beautiful.
Located deep in the woods in a quiet area, this trail is less-used and very enjoyable. It connects with a more relaxing section and is easy to hike.
They have a nature center towards the SW corner of the park next to the woods. Majority of the park is not shaded on the trail so lots of direct sunlight.

This trail connects Center Loop, Grandview Loop, and Turtle Loop together.  It is essential for hikers doing Grandview to hike some portion of this trail.

Its biggest characteristic is its rocks.  There are a lot of them.  Most of them are decomposed chunks of limestone, fist-sized or smaller, but there are also larger slabs of limestone for good measure.  At least there isn't much elevation change.

This trail begins at the creek and gradually winds up a narrow slot canyon. The singletrack path can be slippery and washed out following wet weather. Find all 6 slot canyons to complete the 6 Ravine Challenge.
Access fee required to enter the state park.  There is parking at the "end" of the trail, where there is also access to the beach.  Vault toilets are also near the end of the trail.
The trail begins behind the Canyon Inn pool and travels toward the Recreation Field, McCormickâs Cove Nature Preserve, and the CCC fire tower. Trail 4 ends on the road near Canyon Inn.

This trail leads through Kickapoo Ravine, which is part of the 6 Ravine Challenge at Shades State Park.  The trail passes through the slot canyon and towards the bank of Swan Creek. The loop connects with Trail 8 - Shawnee Canyon. Expect a singletrack dirt trail which becomes treacherous after significant rainfall.

Begins behind the CCC Recreation Hall, ventures into McCormickâs Cove Nature Preserve and ends between family cabins 11 and 12. Trail 2 also offers access to the Quarry Loop Trail for observation of the Old State House Quarry.

Accessed from the Buffalo Trace Trail, the Waterfall Trail offers hikers some more technical terrain, steeper climbs, a hike through a rocky gulley, stream crossings, and views of a gorgeous, if small, waterfall. This is a rocky trail with some narrow areas between trees and along hillsides.

The trail has lake views and various junctions with other trails, camping areas, and even passes by two boat ramps. You'll follow a gravel road for part of the trail and travel through a small stand of pines. The trail will take you below the dam but you can cross on the top of the dam also. Follow trail markers and use the Hiking Project mobile app to complete the Lake Trail.

To get to the trailhead, park in the parking lot overlooking the lake. Once parked, you'll see a big green transformer next to a pine tree. That is the trailhead. The park recommends hikers go clockwise and bikers go counter clockwise. Hikers are to give bikers the right of way. 

The trail is really fun and covers a lot of different terrain. It crosses over the lake in multiple spots as well as all of the creeks feeding into the lake. While there aren't any major hills, be prepared for many small ups and downs the entire way around the lake.

No matter where you start this trail from, it's a fairly easy hike. There are a few steeper grades though the hills and parts of the trail can stay pretty muddy after a good rain. It has several connections with other trails in the park allowing you to hike all day if you wanted. Overall, it's a great nature hike, taking you through the Bird Sanctuary portion of the lake as well as spending plenty of time wandering through the woods.

This is a one mile paved loop around Indiana State Universityâs Memorial Stadium, in the shape of the State of Indiana. Great for a family hike. Additionally, there are exercise stations dispersed around the loop.

This is a biking trail that allows for foot traffic. Be respectful of other users and stay alert while on the trail. 

Schooner Trace Trail is a very technical mountain biking trail; expect to see many features specific to biking. This trail features very narrow singletrack, steep climbs, and frequent mountain biking features. Expect lots of rocky sections, ledges, large logs, tight switchbacks, and even areas that combine all of the above! 

The trail winds through a beautiful part of the park, so be sure to take a few moments to appreciate the hills surrounding the trail as well. The Schooner Trace trailheads are located on either end of the Walnut Trail.

The B&O Trail follows the old Baltimore & Ohio railway. The trail is paved and lined with plenty of trees and some nice yellow "flowers" (probably just a weed of some sort). There are lots of birds and chipmunks to keep you company. The trail is broken up into two segments currently. Construction is underway to connect the two. For more information, click here.
This trail is very remote and comes across no roads or buildings. Hikers need to be prepared to have enough supplies to complete this trek. This is commonly backpacked as part of the Adena Trace.

A sign at the trailhead reads, 

"Terrill Cemetery Grave site visitors may arrange motorized access by contacting: U.S. Forest Service Bedford, IN. 812-275-5987."

Indeed, Terrill Ridge Trail follows the old Axsom Branch Road. Easy for several people to hike abreast.

There are two campsites close to this trail. Campsite #1 is accessible near the southern terminus. The other, campsite #6, is next to a large pond near the northern terminus. The northern site's GPS coordinates are [39.056727, -86.317730]. As you turn sharply west toward the cemetery, there's a narrow (usually soggy) trail spur going north to this location. It's far enough off the trail that passersby will likely not notice you there. This "secrecy" is somewhat reinforced because the spur is not marked on current maps, though there is some signage.

There is no potable water or restroom facilities. Pack your own water or be prepared to filter from streams/lakes. Wear blaze orange during turkey and deer hunting seasons. Some old trail maps may show decommissioned sections of trail. In particular, near the lake, the "new" trail climbs up and away from the lake, NOT alongside the east bank. Hikers yield to horses and should be aware that mountain bikers may also be present. Gasoline and some basic supplies are available in the town of Birdseye.

Parking at a gravel lot on the east end of the Fairfield Causeway, the trail immediately traverses down to the shore of Brookville Lake. In the winter months, the water is subsided and it is fun to hike along the rocky shore and look for shells. Eventually the trail banks to the left and follows a small stream uphill. The unnamed creek usually has water, and will occasionally feature small waterfalls. After you go under some power lines, the trail moves uphill on the right. This is the biggest hill on the trail.

Once at the top, this trail is mostly flat from here on. You'll pass a small pine forest, and eventually come to some cropland. After that, you'll once again go underneath the same power lines, where you can hear them buzzing. Around here, the Templeton Creek Trail veers to the left, while the Fairfield Trail continues to the right. The trail ends at the parking lot for the Glidewell Trail. You can follow the road to the right to access the beach.
